content.$t: deadline: 1/16/2018, category: Launch, subcategory: Symphony CL, icon: launch.svg, owner: Charles Hoskinson, Mark Lundin, Richard Wild, Scott Darby, Tomas Vrana, Helen Broadbridge, Rouska Lundin, summary: The Symphony of Blockchain is an interactive, visual and auditory exploration of bitcoin, cryptocurrency and the blockchain. It is a  research initiative with a single aim: to help bring about greater understanding of both blockchain technology and the ever-expanding (and contracting) cryptocurrency marketplace., github: https://github.com/input-output-hk/symphony, image1: /static/assets/images/roadmap/visual-polish-sm.jpg, image1link: /static/assets/images/roadmap/visual-polish.jpg, image1caption: Visual polish

gsx$owner.$t: Charles Hoskinson, Mark Lundin, Richard Wild, Scott Darby, Tomas Vrana, Helen Broadbridge, Rouska Lundin

gsx$summary.$t: The Symphony of Blockchain is an interactive, visual and auditory exploration of bitcoin, cryptocurrency and the blockchain. It is a  research initiative with a single aim: to help bring about greater understanding of both blockchain technology and the ever-expanding (and contracting) cryptocurrency marketplace.

title.$t: Press coverage in the Next Web

content.$t: deadline: 2/14/2018, category: Press, subcategory: Symphony CL, icon: press.svg, owner: Rouska Lundin, Laurie Wang, Jane Wild, summary: Symphony of Blockchain was featured in The Next Web, an online media source for technology news, business, and culture. In this feature piece, 'Bitcoin as art: This breath-taking visualization might distract you from the dip', TNW described Symphony of Blockchain as a 'mesmerizing live 3D visualization and audio experience that’s not just gorgeous, but also incredibly informative'. The article recognises that blockchain may be one of the most transformative and disruptive forces in the tech world, but it’s a notoriously difficult concept to get across. This project is a beautiful and functional educational tool that makes it easier for people to understand blockchain.

gsx$title.$t: Press coverage in the Next Web

gsx$owner.$t: Rouska Lundin, Laurie Wang, Jane Wild

gsx$summary.$t: Symphony of Blockchain was featured in The Next Web, an online media source for technology news, business, and culture. In this feature piece, 'Bitcoin as art: This breath-taking visualization might distract you from the dip', TNW described Symphony of Blockchain as a 'mesmerizing live 3D visualization and audio experience that’s not just gorgeous, but also incredibly informative'. The article recognises that blockchain may be one of the most transformative and disruptive forces in the tech world, but it’s a notoriously difficult concept to get across. This project is a beautiful and functional educational tool that makes it easier for people to understand blockchain.

content.$t:
deadline: 4/20/2018, category: Research, subcategory: Symphony CL, icon: research.svg, owner: Scott Darby, summary: Conceptual research and experimentation phase building on what we have learned from creating the first iteration of Symphony and developing the ideas further.

Visual: Creating 3D renders of the overall structure of the blockchain and the concepts behind it such as Merkle trees, the mempool, and transactions.

Sound: Research into audio generation examining how blockchain data can be used to generate sound and music at a fundamental level.
, image1: /static/assets/images/roadmap/concept-work-sm.jpg, image1link: /static/assets/images/roadmap/concept-work.jpg, image1caption: Concept work

gsx$owner.$t: Scott Darby

gsx$summary.$t:
Conceptual research and experimentation phase building on what we have learned from creating the first iteration of Symphony and developing the ideas further.

Visual: Creating 3D renders of the overall structure of the blockchain and the concepts behind it such as Merkle trees, the mempool, and transactions.

Sound: Research into audio generation examining how blockchain data can be used to generate sound and music at a fundamental level.

content.$t:
deadline: 5/11/2018, category: Github, subcategory: Symphony CL, icon: mobile.svg, owner: Scott Darby, summary: Updates and refinements to the Symphony project to make it work more efficiently while adding visual polish. 

Visual: Textures and lighting were reworked to enhance the realism of the scene. Merkle tree structures now more accurately match Bitcoin Merkle trees.

Sound: This update includes a more advanced audio generation system where WebAudio synthesis is used to create the sounds. This allows the timbre of the sound to be determined by blockchain data. We are now using the block 'health' to control how distorted the generated sounds are., image1: /static/assets/images/roadmap/launch-sm.jpg, image1link: /static/assets/images/roadmap/launch.jpg, image1caption: Symphony launch

gsx$owner.$t: Scott Darby

gsx$summary.$t:
Updates and refinements to the Symphony project to make it work more efficiently while adding visual polish. 

Visual: Textures and lighting were reworked to enhance the realism of the scene. Merkle tree structures now more accurately match Bitcoin Merkle trees.

Sound: This update includes a more advanced audio generation system where WebAudio synthesis is used to create the sounds. This allows the timbre of the sound to be determined by blockchain data. We are now using the block 'health' to control how distorted the generated sounds are.

content.$t:
category: Research, subcategory: Symphony CL, icon: research.svg, owner: Scott Darby, Helen Broadbridge, Mark Lundin, summary: Exploring how the trees could animate

Researching efficient algorithms for generating tree geometry

Addressing real-time 3D performance concerns and testing approaches to display the geometry

Building a 'level of detail' system, so that the image complexity is reduced as the viewer 'moves away' fromthe image

Ways the tree can be inspected/viewed in isolation

How to interactively explain what a Merkle tree is to the user

Explore the idea of exposing the roots through the surface that the crystals grow from, perhaps as a network health indicator
, image1: /static/assets/images/roadmap/merkle-tree-prototype-sm.jpg, image1link: /static/assets/images/roadmap/merkle-tree-prototype.jpg, image1caption: Merkle tree prototype

gsx$owner.$t: Scott Darby, Helen Broadbridge, Mark Lundin

gsx$summary.$t:
Exploring how the trees could animate

Researching efficient algorithms for generating tree geometry

Addressing real-time 3D performance concerns and testing approaches to display the geometry

Building a 'level of detail' system, so that the image complexity is reduced as the viewer 'moves away' fromthe image

Ways the tree can be inspected/viewed in isolation

How to interactively explain what a Merkle tree is to the user

Explore the idea of exposing the roots through the surface that the crystals grow from, perhaps as a network health indicator

content.$t:
category: Research, subcategory: Symphony CL, icon: research.svg, owner: Scott Darby, Helen Broadbridge, Mark Lundin, summary: Exploring using transaction IDs as a source of randomness to control irregularities shown on the crystal surface

Exploring generation of unique textures based on transaction (tx) data

Dynamic loading of textures based on viewer distance

Exploring ways of using tx parameters to control aspects of crystal geometry

Animations of crystals as they are being created

Replay history and see transaction crystals growing based on the time they were made

Calculating unspent transaction output ratios and how they affect the colour: fully spent transactions are lifeless, unspent are buzzing with energy

The sound of spent and unspent transactions in the overall sonic landscape

Look into how music theory can be used in the sound, such as circle of fifths and musical scales

Explore building up complex sounds entirely from simple components, ie, additive synthesis where sonic complexity is achieved by the layering of many sine waves

When a transaction is spent, it could be visualised moving from the transaction output

Explore ways in which energy and light can be visualised

Investigate varying the speed at which the transaction moves related to the fee attached
, image1: /static/assets/images/roadmap/transactions-prototype-sm.jpg, image1link: /static/assets/images/roadmap/transactions-prototype.jpg, image1caption: Transactions prototype

gsx$owner.$t: Scott Darby, Helen Broadbridge, Mark Lundin

gsx$summary.$t:
Exploring using transaction IDs as a source of randomness to control irregularities shown on the crystal surface

Exploring generation of unique textures based on transaction (tx) data

Dynamic loading of textures based on viewer distance

Exploring ways of using tx parameters to control aspects of crystal geometry

Animations of crystals as they are being created

Replay history and see transaction crystals growing based on the time they were made

Calculating unspent transaction output ratios and how they affect the colour: fully spent transactions are lifeless, unspent are buzzing with energy

The sound of spent and unspent transactions in the overall sonic landscape

Look into how music theory can be used in the sound, such as circle of fifths and musical scales

Explore building up complex sounds entirely from simple components, ie, additive synthesis where sonic complexity is achieved by the layering of many sine waves

When a transaction is spent, it could be visualised moving from the transaction output

Explore ways in which energy and light can be visualised

Investigate varying the speed at which the transaction moves related to the fee attached

content.$t:
category: Research, subcategory: Symphony CL, icon: research.svg, owner: Scott Darby, Helen Broadbridge, Mark Lundin, summary: Generation of sound based on mining data, ie the hash rate

Look at the software used to mine and the processes behind it. Can we use this to drive the sound? 

Can we use  the process of guessing hashes and validating transactions as a source of sound?

Look at controlling the color of the environment/lighting based on the mining intensity

gsx$owner.$t: Scott Darby, Helen Broadbridge, Mark Lundin

gsx$summary.$t:
Generation of sound based on mining data, ie the hash rate

Look at the software used to mine and the processes behind it. Can we use this to drive the sound? 

Can we use  the process of guessing hashes and validating transactions as a source of sound?

Look at controlling the color of the environment/lighting based on the mining intensity

content.$t:
category: Research, subcategory: Symphony CL, icon: research.svg, owner: Scott Darby, Helen Broadbridge, Mark Lundin, summary: Create a cloud of particles or fog with colours and densities determined by transaction fees

The mempool and unconfirmed transaction count indicate how 'healthy' the network is: explore how this could be used in the sound bed

Explore efficient real-time approaches to rendering fog and particles

gsx$owner.$t: Scott Darby, Helen Broadbridge, Mark Lundin

content.$t: category: Research, subcategory: Symphony CL, icon: research.svg, owner: Mark Lundin, Helen Broadbridge, summary: Symphony Augmented Reality is both a physical and digital exploration into the concepts behind blockchain as a technology. With a focus on Bitcoin, we aim to create physical, augmented installations

gsx$owner.$t: Mark Lundin, Helen Broadbridge

gsx$summary.$t: Symphony Augmented Reality is both a physical and digital exploration into the concepts behind blockchain as a technology. With a focus on Bitcoin, we aim to create physical, augmented installations

content.$t: category: Research, subcategory: Symphony CL, icon: research.svg, owner: Richard Wild, Scott Darby, Juli Sudi, Helen Broadbridge, Mark Lundin, summary: The proof of concept for the virtual reality Symphony will take the form of a collection of 360° video photo spheres with accompanying audio that the user can navigate between. The photo spheres will show high quality 3D concept renders from various camera locations. Each location will focus on an interesting part of the 3D blockchain world. There will be a visual head-up display (HUD) overlay that can be toggled to show information about the structures., image1: /static/assets/images/roadmap/VR-proof-of-concept-sm.jpg, image1link: /static/assets/images/roadmap/VR-proof-of-concept.jpg, image1caption: VR Proof of concept

gsx$owner.$t: Richard Wild, Scott Darby, Juli Sudi, Helen Broadbridge, Mark Lundin

gsx$summary.$t: The proof of concept for the virtual reality Symphony will take the form of a collection of 360° video photo spheres with accompanying audio that the user can navigate between. The photo spheres will show high quality 3D concept renders from various camera locations. Each location will focus on an interesting part of the 3D blockchain world. There will be a visual head-up display (HUD) overlay that can be toggled to show information about the structures.

content.$t: category: Research, subcategory: Symphony CL, icon: research.svg, owner: Scott Darby, Helen Broadbridge, Mark Lundin, summary: Each block is represented as a plane with crystals extruded from the surface. The crystals represent the block transactions. The dimensions of the crystals will be determined by the transaction data and the overall health of the network when the transaction was made. The crystal color and emissive properties will be based on the ratio of spent to unspent outputs for the transaction

gsx$owner.$t: Scott Darby, Helen Broadbridge, Mark Lundin

gsx$summary.$t: Each block is represented as a plane with crystals extruded from the surface. The crystals represent the block transactions. The dimensions of the crystals will be determined by the transaction data and the overall health of the network when the transaction was made. The crystal color and emissive properties will be based on the ratio of spent to unspent outputs for the transaction

title.$t: VR Proof of Concept - Merkle Trees [Visual]

content.$t: category: Research, subcategory: Symphony CL, icon: research.svg, owner: Scott Darby, Helen Broadbridge, Mark Lundin, summary: The Merkle tree branches connect to the base of the crystals and the root connects to a channel connecting one tree to the next. The channel is a representation of the pointer between blocks.

gsx$title.$t: VR Proof of Concept - Merkle Trees [Visual]

gsx$owner.$t: Scott Darby, Helen Broadbridge, Mark Lundin

gsx$summary.$t: The Merkle tree branches connect to the base of the crystals and the root connects to a channel connecting one tree to the next. The channel is a representation of the pointer between blocks.

content.$t: category: Research, subcategory: Symphony CL, icon: research.svg, owner: Scott Darby, Helen Broadbridge, Mark Lundin, summary: Sitting at the front of the chain, newly spent transaction outputs collect here and are represented as clouds of gas. The transaction output aggregate determines the size of each cloud and the color is determined by the fees.

gsx$owner.$t: Scott Darby, Helen Broadbridge, Mark Lundin

gsx$summary.$t: Sitting at the front of the chain, newly spent transaction outputs collect here and are represented as clouds of gas. The transaction output aggregate determines the size of each cloud and the color is determined by the fees.

content.$t: category: Research, subcategory: Symphony CL, icon: research.svg, owner: Mark Lundin, summary: Research starts on Cardano blocks and the protocol system. Understand and research the unique features of Cardano and how it compares with Bitcoin. What interesting stories does the data show that can be represented and compared visually? , github: https://github.com/input-output-hk/symphony
